snippet: Five days after the U.S. bombed an Afghan hospital, the president’s personal apology appeared to do little to satisfy the leader of the doctors group.
abstract: Pres Obama issues rare personal apology to Dr Joanne Liu, international president of Doctors Without Borders, for bombing of Kunduz, Afghanistan, hospital by American forces; Liu renews call for independent investigation into incident, expressing doubt as to objectivity of three investigations that have been opened.

byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and SOMINI SENGUPTA
byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Washington, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations. Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Washington, and Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva.

lead_paragraph: Five days after the U.S. bombed an Afghan hospital, the president’s personal apology appeared to do little to satisfy the leader of the doctors group.

headline.main: Obama Issues Rare Apology Over Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Afghanistan
headline.print_headline: Obama Issues Rare Apology Over Bombing

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
